awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Research Experience for Undergraduates in Physics at Lehigh University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Lehigh University, which will provide fourteen undergraduate students each summer the opportunity to participate in ten weeks of research on topics in astrophysics, atomic and molecular physics, biophysics, condensed matter physics, optics, nanotechnology, plasma physics, and statistical physics. The program involves research, weekly faculty seminars and lab tours, a student symposium at the end of the summer, other professional development opportunities, and various social functions that foster the interaction of undergraduate students with faculty and graduate students. A group housing arrangement greatly enhances both the academic and social experiences of the participants.

Program participants gain research experience at a critical point in their undergraduate careers, as well as an excellent preview of graduate school. The students make significant contributions to a wide range of research projects during their summer work. Over the past 25 years, more than two-thirds of the participants in Lehigh's program have gone on to graduate studies in science and engineering, and most of the remaining students obtained jobs in fields of science and technology. The program has an important impact in enabling promising students to pursue careers in science and other technical disciplines, and is informed by an on-going evaluation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The Physics department at Lehigh University has hosted successful summer research programs for the past 35 years. This 3-year grant was designed to support an average of 14 students for the summers of 2019, 2020, 2021.  However, the COVID-pandemic required serious adjustment to the program. Consequently, the program supported 16 students into the 2019 as a regular on-site program. In 2021, the program was executed remotely for 11 students. Several of them opted for a shortened program with the prospect to experience the full program the next year. Consequently, several students came back for the summer of 2021 for which the program was again on-site and hosted a total of 15 students. Remainder of funds were used to host programs in summer 2022 and 2023 for 10 and 2 students respectively. 

The program offers a deep exposure to research for the students by immersing them in research groups that perform state-of-the-art research on a diverse set of fields of physics ranging from very fundamental areas (such as String Theory, Nuclear Physics, Astrophysics) to classical areas (such as Atomic and Molecular Physics, Statistical Physics) to areas that find applications in technology, energy and health (Condensed Matter Physics, Optics, Biophysics). More than 15 Lehigh faculty members have been involved as advisors for the program. The program offered a variety of career development elements and activities. In particular, students are given full exposure to other research programs in the Lehigh Physics department as well as Computer Science and Engineering through faculty seminars, lab tours, and visits to campus facilities.  Some students were given the opportunity to work in research labs abroad or at at National Labs. Several students were involved in university/industry collaborations getting exposed to research and development in the private sector.    and collaborated with researchers in industry.  This sought after program receives an average of 500 excellent applicants every year.  The quality of the students is very high as indicated by a high average GRE. Students presented their research work at conferences and were co-authors on research publications. 

Broader Impact: Special attention was given to the participation of ethnic minorities that are underrepresented in Physics. Through targeted recruitment strategies significant the program was able to shape a very diverse and inclusive  participant cohort with 30% of the students with traditionally underrepresented ethnic backgrounds and 50% non-male students.  The program offered a group housing arrangement which has been one of the most successful aspects of the program. During the summers the program was in person at Lehigh on-site, the students occupied an entire residential building on campus and shared that building with a Computer Science REU cohort. They were given great independence in organizing and running their living group. This helped develop a very strong group identity for the cohort, resulting in peer networks that have lasted beyond the duration of the REU program. In surveys taken by the students, the program receives very high marks.  In particular, a significant number of students stated that they were more likely to pursue a research career after they finish college. These findings are reflected in the extensive statistics that the program has collected since 1989. It was found that the students who take part in the Lehigh program are very likely to pursue advanced degrees or careers in science and technology. The majority (67%) entered advanced degree programs in STEM fields as defined by the NSF.
